Redmon_&_Vale:
{{Infobox musical artist | name = Redmon & Vale | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = group_or_band | origin = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | years_active = 1997â€“2000 | label = [[DreamWorks Records|DreamWorks Nashville]] | associated_acts = [[Carolyn Dawn Johnson]] | website = | past_members = Allison Redmon
Tina Vale }} '''Redmon & Vale''' was an American [[country music]] duo formed in 1997 by Allison Redmon and Tina Vale, both of whom served as vocalists. They met through a common friend, with whom they initially performed as a trio before deciding to work as a duo instead after the trio split up. The duo released a self-titled studio album and two singles in 1999 on [[DreamWorks Records]].{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p376046/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Redmon & Vale biography |accessdate=2008-07-24 |last=Ankeny |first=Jason |work=[[Allmusic]]}} The album included two singles, both of which charted on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' country charts. Jeffrey B. Remz of ''[[Country Standard Time]]'' gave the album a negative review, saying that it "mine[d] the generic, overproduced field of bland pop country."{{cite web |url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2332 |title=Redmon and Vale|accessdate=2008-07-24 |last=Remz |first=Jeffrey B. |work=[[Country Standard Time]]}} A reviewer for ''[[The Technique]]'', the student newspaper for the [[Georgia Institute of Technology]], gave the album a more positive review, noting that the two singers seemed to focus more on harmonies than most other country groups.{{cite web |url=http://dev.nique.gatech.edu/issues/1999-09-17/entertainment/8 |title=Redmon & Vale: Country Can Be Good |accessdate=2008-07-24 |last=Dickenson |first=Darren |date=1999-09-17 |work=[[The Technique]] }}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The album's first single, "If I Had a Nickel (One Thin Dime)" reached No. 65 on the country charts, while the second single, "Squeezin' the Love Outta You", peaked at No. 74. The latter was also recorded by [[Carolyn Dawn Johnson]] (who co-wrote it) on her 2004 album ''[[Dress Rehearsal (Carolyn Dawn Johnson album)|Dress Rehearsal]]''. ==Discography== {{Infobox album |
